A runner is the player who scores by running around first, second, and third base, and then touching home plate.

A run is a score in baseball made by a runner who advances around first, second and third base and returns safely to home plate, touching the bases in that order, before three outs are recorded and all obligations to reach base safely on batted balls are met or assured.

In baseball, a runner is the player who is on base and attempting to advance to the next base. Runners on second or third base are considered to be in scoring position since a normal hit, even a single, will often score them.

In baseball, a batter or batter-runner is a person whose turn it is to face the pitcher.
The batter-runner must reach first base safely. If he is tagged out while running, or if he overruns first base, he is out.
A batter is a person whose role in baseball is to attempt to hit the pitched ball with the bat.
A batter is a person in baseball who tries to hit the ball with a bat.
Baseball is a bat-and-ball game played between two opposing teams who take turns batting and fielding.
Running is a method of terrestrial locomotion allowing humans and other animals to move rapidly on foot.
